result.markdown: --- title: "Git commands overview" author: "stesiam" description: "A list with most common used git commands to start using Git." categories: [Git] fig-cap-location: bottom date: "2022-11-04" freeze: true image: git_new.png image-alt: "Git commands" toc: true toc-title: Table of contents toc-location: left title-block-banner: true citation: true nocite: '@*' csl: apa-6th-edition bibliography: references.bib format: html: freeze: true code-link: true execute: echo: true editor_options: markdown: wrap: 80 --- ## Introduction ### Version control systems ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ::: ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} trends_vcs_tidy %>% ggplot(aes(x= Month, y = counts)) + geom_line(aes(color = VCS)) + labs(title = "Trends on Version Control Systems", subtitle = "Compare trends of Git and SVN (Subversion) from 2004 to 2022", caption = "Data source: Google Trends") + theme_classic() ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](2022-11-04-Git-Commands_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=672} ::: ::: ### The case of Git ## Git initial settings ```bash git config --global user.name "YourName" git config --global user.email your_email ``` and you can verify your settings by using the following command : ```bash git config --list ``` Here is the output on my machine : ![Output of git-config command](git-config-output.png) ## Beginner's workflow | Git command | Description | | :---: | :---:| | git init | Title | | git add | Text | | git commit | Text | ## Work with branches ## Working with others ## Git and GitHub ## Other topics ## Acknowledgements {.appendix} Image by Daniel Skovran from Pixabay
